file-roller looks at file extention not file header to determine type
file-roller looks at file extention not file header to determine type

note.body:
Hi Andre, thank you for the quick reply.
Steps to reproduce as far as the file-roller part is extremely simple:

1. Find a working `tar.gz` file in firefox  (eg: https://en-gb.wordpress.org/latest-en_GB.tar.gz). 
2. Select the "open with" option on firefox and choose to use file-roller
3. File opens successfully.
4. minimise file roller
5. Select the file again and "open with" file-roller a second time. Firefox calls the temporary name of the second download `wordpress-5.3-en_GB.tar-1.gz
6. File roller opens the outer gzip but displays an internal file named 'wordpress-5.3-en_gb.tar-1 which it then fails to open.

Actually, there's an even easier way to reproduce which doesn't need firefox at all:

1. Download or create a working tar.gz file (eg file.tar.gz)
2. Rename to 'file.tar-1.gz'
3. Try opening with file roller and observe that the outer gzip is opened but it then errors when trying to open the inner file.tar-1 as it doesn't recognise the archive.

If you can suggest a distro that would use a later version of file-roller as default (or a way of installing the latest version) then I'd be happy to test against that.

tldr: Why does file-roller care what the file is called rather than deriving its type in the same way the cli command `file` does?

With thanks :)

note.body:
I'm delighted by the professionality and the effort people are putting in these mockups and discussions. I really appreciate it!

There is just one thing that was never questioned in this whole discussion, which I want to address: the **profile images**. They look nice in the design and also help to better distinguish one mail from another without the dividing line, but I think the design doesn't capture reality as good as we might think.

One weak argument is, that from my experience only very few people have profile images for their contacts on desktops, because platforms like WhatsApp or Facebook where these images can be easily gathered from are more bound to mobile devices than to desktops.

However my main argument is that there is a big usage difference between Chat and E-Mail. E-Mail as the name states originates from letters/mail, and allows potentially everyone to send us a mail (at least if our address is known). While Chats are nearly always a communication from one person to another, where we first have to accept with whom we want to chat (for example by adding them as a friend).  This leads to very different usage of email. The following [statistics](https://de.statista.com/statistik/daten/studie/223876/umfrage/e-mail-typen-im-posteingang/) (you might not be able to access it) unfolds that only 14% of the total emails are personal emails, in other words emails from people that potentially can have a profile picture. All the other emails are auto generated content from companies or organisations like newsletters, confirmation mails, email distributors or payment mails.

You might say that the proposed generated letter based profile images help to bridge this gap. In my opinion they are not nearly as unique and memorable as real images and can be quickly mistaken with each other. When looking at other apps like K9 mail they are just distracting me from the email subject without telling me anything useful.

![K9 Mail Example](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/r_MsrPu8gMsGqwUfUgzs9fgCl8a7Vjfsv03Wgd9RbV0DW9r20oXupKOgKZeg2YpjHw=w1920-h978 "K9 Mail")

So I would prefer to drop the profile images or at least make them optional like K9 does to gain extra space for more important features and avoid confusion.

events.target_title: Consider adding Geary to core or removing Contacts

note.body:
> I believe nothing else in GNOME is using Contacts, so it probably doesn't make sense to keep it otherwise. 

I think doing the opposite would be right. Since Evolution currently combines contacts, calendar and Geary they become far more important than before. Feature-wise Evolution-Contacts offer more options than Gnome-Contacts so it should rather be extended than removed.

Isn't Geary using the same contacts that can be managed with Gnome-Contacts? Also Gnome-Calendar does use contacts for birthdays.

events.target_title: Consider adding Geary to core or removing Contacts

note.body:
> You mean *and email* right? 

I meant: Gnome-Calendar, Gnome-Contacts and Geary. But it doesn't matter if we are talking about the software or their purpose.

> Nobody was talking about removing contacts from Evolution, rather the discussion was removing GNOME Contacts from core-apps as without Geary it has limited utility (hence the alternative suggestion is to bring Gearn *in* to core) 

I wasn't talking about removing contacts form evolution either. All I'm saying is that Gnome-Contacts should rather be improved (since it is less powerful compared to the contact management evolution provides) instead of being removed if Evolution is replaced by Geary as the default email program in GNOME.

If Geary does not replace Evolution I can understand your point why you want to remove Gnome-Contacts. Though if I follow the logic Gnome-Calender should also be removed from the core.

events.target_title: Wacom stylus screen mode bug.

note.body:
Sadly GIMP (and/or GTK+) isn't entirely predictable when it comes to tablet problems....

I've never had problems with XP-Pen Star 06 [wireless painting tablet](https://www.xp-pen.com/product/49.html) on my GIMP installation (aside from the occasional failure to detect the tablet at all), unfortunately I'm not quite sure I understand the description. Nonetheless, here's a few quick things to check / rule out:

- Screen/window mode. It should definitely be set to "Screen", so this doesn't seem to be the cause....

- Pen/mouse mode. If, for example, you pick up the pen from point A and put it down on point B but the cursor doesn't immediately snap to the new location, then you've got the stylus set on mouse (relative movement) mode. Check your Wacom tablet control panel to be sure it's on Pen (absolute movement) mode.

note.body:
I executed callgrind and perf, they both report this:
+ Inclusive   Self    Process   Module                  Function
+   49.58%    49.57%  xsltproc  libxml2.so.2.9.1    [.] xmlStrncat
+   48.62%    48.61%  xsltproc  libxml2.so.2.9.1    [.] xmlStrlen

basically meaning that most of the time is used copying strings and measuring strings in my use case.

It seems that maintaing the size of text nodes and the xmlNode could have a huge impact on performance, using some "copy-on-write" or immutable text logic could cut execution time by a big factor

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
The path is starting under xsltApplySequenceConstructor:
- xsltValueOf => xsltCopyTextString => xsltAddTextString
- xsltCopyText => xsltAddTextString
then
- xsltAddTextString => xmlStrnlen (half of the time)
- xsltAddTextString => xmlNodeAddContent => xmlNodeAddContentLen => xmlStrncat (the other half)

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
After some debugging, I understand what happens: 
* we use EXSLT and concatenation cache is NULLed any time a EXSLT function is called (cannot grasp why there is code duplication is this region btw), "cur->pswi == xsltExtMarker ==> ctxt->lasttext = NULL"
* we use xsl:variable quite a lot as our XSL is pretty complex, there is only one such "lasttext", but when xsl:variable elements are encountered a new target node is created, and first concatenation empties "lasttext" and when interned string are copied to it "lasttext" is invalidated as well

For problem 1, using systematically xsltAddChild in libexslt could bring the opportunity to ensure that the "lasttext" cache is invalidated properly and thus avoid the cache systematic trashing. Another way is to invalidate only for the few functions that actually do xmlAddChild... my preference goes to ensure that the cache is never trashed
For problem 2, probably need to a few entries, not just one, maybe just 2, top level + first level of xsl:variable

A more impacting solution would be to do some homework in libxml2, supporting a new type of "dynamic text node", which would allow efficient concatenation (putting lasttuse/lasttsize in xmlNode more or less), simplifying drastically all of this. 

If you want I can work on that and try a patch.

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
Indeed could append text nodes and coalesce them when we are finished with the direct parent node, a single scan per node, gathering sequences of text and replacing them with a single text node for each, linear time.
Possible ?

events.target_title: In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.
In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.

note.body:
Having studied the code, I see that the **various on_*_value_changed** calls cannot distinguish if they are called by the user/GTK directly or are called as a consequence of the adjustment of other Buttons.

For example: When user sets the **Center** to **Both** it will (possibly) need to adjust the values of **Left**, **Top** etc. However, If the user presses the **-** or **+** of **Left** directly, you would like to modify the **Center** value from **Both** to **Vertical**, as only the horizontal part is non-centered anymore.

I assume this conflict can be solved by making **adjust_*_value** (similar as the **on_*_value_changed** functions) which firstly block the trigger, secondly modify the value and finally unblock the trigger.

events.target_title: In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.

note.body: It seems the signal [value-changed](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkSpinButton.html#GtkSpinButton-value-changed) is already emitted if the SpinButton gets into focus, but has no value changed. This means that repetitively pressing the Tab key will force an update of each of the value. The image will move due to rounding errors.

events.target_title: NetworkManager openconnect fails to connect with immediate failure

note.body:
We looked at it once again and definately the problem is with parsing gateway strings. NM-OpenConnect assumes that all users are connecting to Pulse Server without realm string i.e. ra.comp.com.pl and change this into https://ra.comp.com.pl when executing openconnect with parameters.

Our case is we are usings realm and assigned sign-in paged to it. That is when user connect to ra.comp.com.pl/compa (/compsa is the sign-in page for that realm). As we see whatewer you fill in gateway part of form is truncated to FQDN without URL /compsa at the end. Since we do not have default sign-in page defines Pulse Server returns error "The page you requested could not be found.". I do personally think that we are facing improperly parsed gateway problem here. I think resolution would be to keep whole GATEWAY string as-is and pass it to executable.

Interesting part is that when we use Juniper as protocol everything is parsed properly :-)

Are there any developers reviewing issues here? 

Regards
J.

events.target_title: PNG gAMA chunk is silently ignored

note.body:
This is part of the PNG specification and GIMP should implement the specification right. PNG's specification is remarkably simple compared to some other formats. In particular the specification tells that if a gAMA chunk is present and the chunks iCCP, sRGB and cHRM are absent, then the application has to take gAMA into account. GIMP should do all its possible to render the image as close as possible to what it is supposed to look like. The gamma Display Filter option seems to prove that this could be programmed fairly easily in GIMP, and would not require any resampling of the image.

If it is too hard to achieve (because the program GIMP may not know what is actual effective gamma (the gamma from the channel values sent to the operating system to the actual pixel on the display) ), there should at least be some /coherence/ between the possibilities. By coherence I precisely mean the following:  if the user is able to set their display and os settings so that an sRGB image is displayed right, then all other color modes should also display right as per the PNG specification.

As a matter of fact, there are computer rendered images that are encoded with gamma=1 (they use a linear color coding).

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
could I ask one more question ? the way I see it, the source of the problem is not the fact that vte *is* overriding these chars, but the fact that it's decision whether to do so or not is a bit over-cautious. My point is that the font that I'm using (and I've tried couple of them) do have the characters inside the font so there's no need to manually render them.

if it would be possible, I would like to help in solving this issue. I may not be the best coder out there, but this issue, believe me or not, is important to me. Here's couple of solutions that I came up with:

1/ inside `_vte_draw_unichar_is_local_graphic` - check whether the font has the character implemented. Unfortunetely, I can see that the function only receives a char as a parameter, however it's not like the font is changed everytime the char is rendered, therefore I could imagine that a constructor (or some other function which is called once font instance is assigned) could check this and create a hashmap of supported characters and then this infamous function could check against such a hashmap and actually know which chars are missing and need to be manually rendered. In other words - if there is a font which is very basic and lacks glyphs then it would still use the shaded blocks. I do understand the rationale behind this functionality and do not want to dispute it - I would just like to tweak it a bit.

2/ create an option to override `_vte_draw_unichar_is_local_graphic` result. In other words, if I know that I'm using a font which has all these glyphs, I could just select an option in gnome-terminal and be happy. Even if I'd have to manually enter hex values, it would still be an improvement

3/ environmental variable of the above - which seems very hacky and ugly and has the least likelihood of success.

currently, as I understand the only thing that I can do is to:

1/ use non-vte emulator like xterm, konsole
2/ compile my own version of vte and replace the system one
3/ repeate the above everytime there's an gnome stack update

this seems like a massive overkill, especially given that I do have the glyphs in the font in the first place :-)

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
well, just for reference - this is from urxvt, the chars are loaded from font and that's an ncurses window where I put them next to each other. It all displays perfectly. I was completely unaware that this decision (to override rendering of the glyphs) was made based on font-irrelevant issues. My point is simply that these 2 or 3 glyphs in question are rendered wrong. A triangle is still a triangle, even if you move it up or down couple of pixels. A smiley is still a smiley, but a checkerboard/brick pattern is not a solid block. In this regard, using rxvt is not a free choice at all, since gnome-terminal doesn't allow me to use a font I know does have a char. Konsole has an option to render the glyphs like you pointed out, but gnome-terminal does not.

![2591-urxvt](/uploads/81cdd80919bebaa01638ec82be8910d9/2591-urxvt.png)

I don't want to pick up a flamewar though, you have explained everything quite nicely. Thank you :)

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
> That's not correct. Nothing in these characters' specification says they should be using a checkerboard or brick pattern. They are 'light/medium/dark shade', and their display as dots in the fonts is simply due to dithering being the way to achieve an approximation of the true rendering

I believe we are talking about two different things. You are talking about a unicode specification and I'm talking about a font. That's why we have fonts in the first place. If somebody doesn't like how an "o" character looks like, he can pick another font, in which an "o" would be a small dot, or an ellipse instead of a circle. That's why there are some fonts which have some of the digits below the center line (e.g. https://cdncms.fonts.net/images/c098e4e88991a263/A_Oldstyle_Figures.jpg ). If memory serves me correctly, back in the days there was a font called... webdings ? which took it to the whole new level and replaced the "regular" charcodes with some graphics. The user chooses a font knowingly and willingly. I can of course agree that you do not find the bricked pattern visually appealing, but this is a matter of personal taste, not what the font provides you with. I find them way more appealing than the shaded versions, but that's actually not my concern. My concern is that - why would you render an, say, "capital A" character (0x0041) by using a font-provided glyph, but you don't think it's a good idea for 0x2551? Again, I would like to stress out that I would **totally** understand this behavior of the code had the font not provided a glyph - in the end you have to display something on the screen, right?. But if the user chooses a font that he finds aesthetically pleasing and then cannot see it's full glory? What's the benefit of that .. :-)

To sum it up - I still believe this is a bug, not a feature. If I choose a font which implements the character then by all means I as an user am fully aware how ugly or unappealing this character may look. Taste is such a subjective matter after all.

I guess we'll have to agree to disagree :) although it is quite sad that in order for me to use a font that I want to I have to compile my own version of libvte.. cheers

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
it's so sad that you are using an argument like 'ugly'. Ugly or Beautiful are very subjective. Again - if you don't like the bricked pattern then you could choose a font which doesn't provide it at all and then be greeted with the shaded block.

I can already see this is a lost cause and again, it is very, very sad that I have to manually compile a custom version of vte just to display a character from the font (that the font provides). This is particularly ironic, given the fact that I cannot display a font character in modern linux desktop environment which I could in a DOS environment which was nowhere near the level of linux. Just out of curiosity, I've also checked qterminal from lxqt as well as terminal in chrome os - both of them display a font-provided glyph.

ok, I promise not to write anything more and you may safely remove this issue. thanks for the explanation. It just looks to me like you're trying to know better than the user what he chooses to see on the screen.

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
Sorry for breaking my promise, but I couldn't resist..

I don't know why you keep referring to the bitmap font. I only asked about bitmap fonts because I thought that vte was ignoring ttf glyph for this particular char, but because vte has an if statement based on a char code, it's irrelevant what font type will I use (bitmap or ttf) because it will ignore the char either way and draw a shaded box. I tried ubuntu mono, monospace and Hacky fonts. To my knowledge, they are true type fonts, with this char implemented (present in the font)

Basically I started all this because I wanted to create a demo which would resemble the look of turbo vision:

![tvision](https://www.jasondl.ee/images/2018/tv_demo.png)

unfortunetely, the bricked pattern is essential to this iconic look and feel and without it, I can't achieve this. I find the bricked pattern particularly appealing, but that is just my subjective taste (though I can understand if you find it ugly). For the time being, my only option is to use one of the terminals I mentioned (rxvt, qterminal, alacritty, etc) or compile my own version of vte. Which is quite frustrating because I use both gnome-terminal and tillix on a regular basis - I like them a lot. I also checked the "regular" tty in linux (ctrl + alt + f2) and it also displays the character.

Once again, sorry for my stubborn attention to detail. To me it's obvious that if a code is not loading a character from a font which provides it it constitues a bug. And yes, if you still prefer to draw it manually then rendering the glyph with pixels would technically still be a bug to me (because it would still not load a glyph from the font) but at least it would definetely be an improvement. However the ideal solution from my end point of view would be just to render the glyph (if the font provides it) and if somebody doesn't like the look of it (as you were kind to point out - the chance of that [that being a typical user seeing this particular glyph] is 1 in a trillion) he could simply change the font to one which doesn't provide the glyph and then vte would render the shaded block. As I mentioned, there are quite few terminals which do display the glyph (yesterday I even checked terminal on Mac OS which also displays it, though I don't have access to any windows machine to check what does it do) and initially I thought that there was something wrong with my code which made the char not appear.

kind regards

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
I'll try to explain the best I can, although take it with some grain of salt.

actually, first and foremost - I begin to understand why it's impractical to load the glyphs *all the time*. Basically, I created a pattern of lines (constructed of a solid block - 0x2588 IIRC) and displayed it in alacritty and it does show gaps between the glyphs, instead of a solid line. vte displays a solid line so it's definetely better-looking, not going to argue about it.

now, back to Turbo Vision. It is a long abandoned product. as I understand it was only used in DOS-era and it uses extended ascii characters to presend a TUI (Text-user-interface). I think that we can think of it as an old idea of ncurses - you could have multiple windows (all created from text), interact with mouse and resize them, and the windows could be located on top of each other. I have no idea if it was possible to change the font per application in DOS text-based mode, I doubt it. I think that it was possible to change the font for the DOS itself which would then translate to other programs. That's how it was possible to display localized diactric characters - basically the font would replace the characters which the user was unlikely to use on regular basis and I think they called it a codepage. as for the product evolving, I have once heard that Borland created 'Graphics vision' but I think that this was in the days of windows 3.11 era and the product never really took off and Borland has then replaced it with Delphi / C++ Builder suites (which were just calling winAPI under the hood). Again - I'm not much of an expert on this since I stopped using windows ages ago.

It [the text version - turbo vision] has since been ported to linux, I suppose - just for fun. The screenshot I posted is a screenshot of a Java port called jexer, but there is also a linux port called tvision. What I was doing was I was simply trying to write some dummy C code in order to see what does it take to display the iconic bricked background pattern and I got interested why I could not achieve this, which braught me here :)

I can only speculate that the reason why Borland decided to use a bricked character for the canvas / background was to distinguish the background from the "regular" windows which could also be grey. The background seems to be displayed with a blue font on grey background and so if you draw a fully shaded grey window you can tell one from another.

I'm not really sure what I should see at your second screenshot - it looks perfect to me, exactly because there are gaps between the bricks. Although I suppose that without gaps it would look equally nice

events.target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
I confirm it fails with other SNI-routing services too. I have peeked into the source code (nm-openconnect-service.c) and it says the following in comments:

```c
/* The actual gateway to use (after redirection) comes from the auth
	   dialog, so it's in the secrets hash not the properties */
```
and later:
```c
/* We just need the WebVPN cookie, and the final IP address of the gateway
   (after HTTP redirects, which do happen). All the certificate/SecurID 
   nonsense can be handled for us, in the user's context, by auth-dialog */
```

It would be great to make it use DNS name instead of IP when passing to the openconnect binary. I recon forcefully passing the value of the "Gateway" field from the connection preferences may break things (in case redirects really happen) but maybe just adding a switch to use name for SNI would be a solution?

events.target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body: I have just checked it and openconnect itself does handle redirects ("Got HTTP response: HTTP/1.0 302 Temporary moved" being returned on console when using openconnect directly and subsequent calls using the new URL) so why not to leave that to openconnect and simply pass the "Gateway" value to it?

events.target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
That made me try to find out a way to pass the Gateway value verbatim to openconnect binary. I have made the following change in the code:
```c
--- a/nm-openconnect-service.c	2019-11-27 13:08:38.001128812 +0100
+++ b/nm-openconnect-service.c	2019-11-27 13:08:47.013128355 +0100
@@ -412,7 +412,7 @@
 
 	/* The actual gateway to use (after redirection) comes from the auth
 	   dialog, so it's in the secrets hash not the properties */
-	props_vpn_gw = nm_setting_vpn_get_secret (s_vpn, NM_OPENCONNECT_KEY_GATEWAY);
+	props_vpn_gw = nm_setting_vpn_get_data_item (s_vpn, NM_OPENCONNECT_KEY_GATEWAY);
 	if (!props_vpn_gw || !strlen (props_vpn_gw) ) {
 		g_set_error (error,
 		             NM_VPN_PLUGIN_ERROR,
```
Now I can successfully connect to the VPN server that is behind the SNI-aware proxy. It may possibly break things in a wider sense (I assume there was a reason for how it is implemented today) but it suits my needs for now. And who knows - maybe it was openconnect's fault back then and is no longer needed - and the fix can find its way to the code? ;)

events.target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
After investigating it somewhat more I have found that name gets replaced with IP after calling `openconnect_obtain_cookie()` function inside `auth-dialog/main.c` and the function comes from the `/usr/include/openconnect.h` being part of the openconnect itself. Additionally, the `openconnect.h` file contains the following:

```c
/* Returns the IP address of the exact host to which the connection
 * was made. In --cookieonly mode or in any other scenario involving
 * a "two stage" connection, it is important to reconnect by IP because
 * the server side may be using DNS trickery for load balancing.
 *
 * If the IP address is unavailable due to the use of a proxy, this will
 * fall back to returning the DNS name. */
const char *openconnect_get_hostname(struct openconnect_info *);

/* Returns the hostname parsed out of the server name URL. This is
 * intended to be used by the validate_peer_cert callback to check that
 * the certificate matches the server name. */
const char *openconnect_get_dnsname(struct openconnect_info *);
```
So it seems that name -> IP change is intentional on that part. The interesting bit is that when you call openconnect binary directly it does handle it properly (i.e. is SNI-aware/compatible).

The other change that can make the nm-openconnect to work in our case is to modify `auth-dialog/main.c` instead of `nm-openconnect-service.c` (as was suggested in the comment above) and change:

```c
--- a/main.c	2019-11-28 15:30:45.290613991 +0100
+++ b/main.c	2019-11-28 15:31:00.498614939 +0100
@@ -1256,7 +1256,7 @@
 		   by nm-openconnect-service to make the connection */
 		key = g_strdup (NM_OPENCONNECT_KEY_GATEWAY);
 		value = g_strdup_printf ("%s:%d",
-					 openconnect_get_hostname(ui_data->vpninfo),
+					 openconnect_get_dnsname(ui_data->vpninfo),
 					 openconnect_get_port(ui_data->vpninfo));
 		g_hash_table_insert (ui_data->secrets, key, value);
 ```

Again - it may break things as there seems to be a reason to use IP, but seems more 'legit' than the previous hack and does the trick for me.

push_data.commit_title: Replace pointer aliasing in unit test

events.target_title: Avoid potential 64-bit pointer aliasing alignment issues
Make gck attribute value allocation aligned for 64bit systems

note.body:
I'm sorry, I totally missed your merge request here, @psumbera . I submitted a new bug report for the same issue in #34 .
The Debian sparc64 build was running into the same issues as reported by you, and I simply patched it up by replacing the 64-bit memory access with memcpy's in !26 . This is a safe option for any platform and will not even incur a runtime cost on any platform where unaligned 64-bit memory access isn't a problem.

I didn't look into the actual reason why the allocated memory wasn't 64-bit aligned in the first place.
IMHO, it would make sense to assure proper memory alignment to avoid inefficient memory access, but I don't see how this can be done in a safe way with the current implementation. As I understand, the memory referenced by the attributes can be arbitrarily aligned due to packing. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

@dueno already merged !27 , but perhaps we can work out something that optimises memory management to avoid the memcpy call? Simply fixing the allocation will not be enough, as the compiler won't recognise the 'safe' pointers and will still generate a memcpy function call. I don't want to go back to pointer aliasing, as this may still pose a risk in the future if pointer semantics change on one platform.

events.target_title: Make gck attribute value allocation aligned for 64bit systems

note.body:
Possibly, but I'm not sure if this is going to help.
The link to the kernel docs I posted in the other issue ( https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/unaligned-memory-access.txt ) mentions the risk of having packed data structures where members aren't ordered by alignment. In the examples mentioned there however, the compiler will at least be able to figure our when it needs to access memory via an unaligned load/store - or add padding to the data strucutre.
This wasn't the case with gcr, because the serialised data structure is treated like an array of bytes.
Consider what happens when you put bools and ulongs side by side - if the serialisation packs them tightly, then unaligned fields are *always* a possibility.

Example:
```
R=refcount B=bool L=ulong
00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09 0a 0b 0c 0d 0e 0f 10 11 12
RRRRRRRRRRR BB RRRRRRRRRRR LLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLL
```

I didn't look at how attributes are actually packed by gcr, but this is certainly something to consider.

note.body:
I have the same issue with my HP Laser 135a scanner.

The issue is also exists for other scanners:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/simple-scan/+bug/1327801

I investigate this issue, and it occurs when there is no `Sane.NAME_CONTRAST` option_descriptor:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/simple-scan/blob/master/src/scanner.vala#L1139

I investigated why Xsane is working, and it seems that xsane is modifing the output data:
1. First by creating Gamma correction function:
  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_correction#Microsoft_Windows,_Mac,_sRGB_and_TV/video_standard_gammas
  https://github.com/kkaempf/xsane/blob/master/src/xsane-gamma.c#L1322
2. Then applying it to every pixel/channel data:
  https://github.com/kkaempf/xsane/blob/master/src/xsane-scan.c#L250

This method is very efficient, and universal. It allows to enable brightness/contrast manipulation for every device.

@robert.ancell I would like to implement that feature. Do you think such patch could be accepted by simple-scan?

note.body:
I have the same problem.

- Pop!_OS 19.10 x86_64
- mutter 3.34.1+git20191107-1ubuntu1~19.10.1pop0~1573683812~19.10~50e928a
- gnome-shell 3.34.1-1ubuntu1pop0~1573148724~19.10~f65f9b1

The `gnome-shell` run as the `gdm` user doesn't quit after I have logged in, and it keeps eating up more RAM. My laptop has an NVIDIA GeForce MX150 and Intel UHD Graphics (Whiskey Lake 3x8 GT2), and is capable of hybrid graphics. gnome-shell leaks memory in both hybrid graphics mode and Intel-only mode.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
Some people have suggested that buggy GNOME shell extensions may be to blame. So far I have disabled all of the non-default extensions, leaving the default ones that came with Pop!_OS running.

The gdm gnome-shell instance *still* won't quit automatically, and it still keeps eating up more RAM.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
@ITwrx There's the `gdm` *process* and then there's the `gdm` *user*.

On my laptop, when I'm logged into a GNOME desktop session, there are two `gnome-shell` processes running: one is run as me, the other is run as the `gdm` user. I'm talking about the `gnome-shell` instance that is run as the `gdm` user. That process is apparently responsible for the login screen, and that's the one that is leaking memory. According to some people on the internet, that `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance is really *not* supposed to keep running after a user has logged into a desktop session, though I cannot speak for the correctness of that claim.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
My laptop has both Intel UHD Graphics (Whiskey Lake 3x8 GT2) and an NVIDIA GeForce MX150. And it is possible switch among three graphics modes (restart required):
- hybrid graphics
- intel-only graphics
- nvidia-only graphics

Here are some of the related, installed drivers and packages:

| package or driver | version |
| ------ | ------ |
| i965-va-driver | 2.3.0-0ubuntu2 |
| xserver-xorg-video-intel | 2:2.99.917+git20190815-1 |
| intel-media-va-driver:amd64 | 19.2.1+dfsg1-2ubuntu1 |
| nvidia-driver-440 [*] | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |
| nvidia-dkms-440 | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |
| xserver-xorg-video-nvidia-440 | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |


I have done more testing and here are my discoveries so far:

If I enable nvidia-only graphics:

- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance responds to SIGHUP and SIGTERM by respawning, complete with the ibus-related child processes;
- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance would immediately use up about 180 MiB RAM right-off-the-bat, and the RAM usage would keep climbing;

If I enable intel-only graphics:

- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance responds to SIGHUP (but not SIGTERM) by respawning. The respawned `gnome-shell` instance will *not* have ibus-related child processes;
- The respawned `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance will start at about 39 MiB RAM usage, and pretty much stay there.

[*] The `nvidia-driver-440` metapackage pulls in *a lot* of real, nvidia-related packages, most of which have the exact same version number, so I'm not going to list them all one-by-one.

events.target_title: Borders of edited parts in PDF format
Snap to top and bottom (edges) too

note.body:
@fmuellner it's very true that the auto maximise using the top edge is a super-useful feature, and we shouldn't give it up. However it is also true that screens are becoming bigger and bigger, and it's not so uncommon to have to compare two documents. While code tends to be be compact on the X Axis, and therefore a left-right comparison is pretty handy, that's not the case for anything that is written text, for example written documents, where the X axis is pretty important.

Maybe, from an user-prospective point of view, a proposal could be to have a combination of top edge and press of a shortcut:
- only top edge --> maximise
- top edge + Super --> split half top 

The bottom edge is not used at the moment, IIRC, so that can actually be used as the hint to have the half split.

Regarding shortcut, a proposal would be to have Super + Top Arrow and Super + Right Arrow, to have consistency with the other two.

My two cents.

Allow layer boundaries to be adjusted automatically

note.body:
I and many other people I know switched from GIMP to Photoshop as soon as they could afford it primarily because this issue is too disruptive to workflow (brush options were the other factor but that has mostly been resolved). It seems like many people don't post about this because they assume that such an important feature can't be that far away, but this issue was reported 17 years ago and is still not a feature. This is why after 16 years of trying GIMP roughly once a year, I am speaking up. I can't stress enough the importance of this feature so please, if anyone reading this has any influence on development priorities, please make this feature a higher priority. In my opinion it by far the most important thing on the roadmap. 

For cases where specific layer sizes are desirable my suggestion is to have a "Lock layer size" checkbox (in the layer properties dialogue) that disables dynamic resizing an enables the layer dimension inputs. The default behaviour for new layers could be a document or program setting, which may be useful for animation projects.

events.target_title: Tiff files generated by GIMP cannot be deleted or used by other programs.

note.body:
My solution to (finally) removing these files (assumes knowledge of basic command line usage):

1. Open a command prompt as an administrator.
1. Use ctrl+alt+del to access the task manager.
1. On the processes tab (with show more details selected). Find and terminate the Windows Explorer task (right-click/end task), which will cause any open explorer windows and your taskbar to disappear.
1. Use the command prompt to delete affected files.
1. Use the command **start explorer.exe** to restart windows explorer.

After you're done, it may be worth rebooting just to be sure everything returns to normal operations. Hope this helps someone.

events.target_title: window titlebar buttons placed left causes flickering text and non responsive buttons

note.body:
It seems to be caused by https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-tweaks/commit/6ecb055b1c2cf75f517ee8a81fc57d9fbb487637
I have tried fixing it myself but without much success.

I can somewhat workaround it with:
```
diff --git a/gtweak/tweakview.py b/gtweak/tweakview.py
index 5de11d6..515d0f1 100644
--- a/gtweak/tweakview.py
+++ b/gtweak/tweakview.py
@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@ class Window(Gtk.ApplicationWindow):
         Gtk.ApplicationWindow.__init__(self,
                                        application=app,
                                        show_menubar=False)
-        self.set_size_request(-1, 700)
+        self.set_size_request(950, 700)
         self.set_position(Gtk.WindowPosition.CENTER)
         self.set_icon_name("org.gnome.tweaks")
 
@@ -168,7 +168,6 @@ class Window(Gtk.ApplicationWindow):
 
     def main_content(self):
         right_box = Gtk.Box(orientation=Gtk.Orientation.VERTICAL)
-        right_box.set_size_request(750, -1)
 
         self.stack = Gtk.Stack()
         self.stack.get_style_context().add_class("main-container")

```
but that defeats the purpose of the change linked above as we won't be able to go below 950x700 anymore, it also exposes yet another regression introduced by the change — switching buttons from left -> right leaves an empty space until the window is redrawn? (eg. resized).

events.target_title: Add way to change audio output (speakers vs headphones) on a per application basis
Add way to change audio output (speakers vs headphones) on a per application basis

note.body:
The extension doesn't provide the functionality in question, I just used it as an idea for design. Sorry for the misunderstanding. 

But even if an extension provided the functionality, extensions are not officially supported and the API is not stable. Relying on a third party, that isn't guaranteed to work between versions, for providing basic functionality is bad design in my opinion.

I'm not saying that extensions should be incorporated into shell as they have their use: customization (e.g. Dash to Dock/Panel) or special configurations (themes, distros such ZorinOS that make gnome more Windows-like) are valid reasons to use extensions. However, using two audio sources concurrently doesn't seem to me like something _that_ special. That's why other DEs provide the functionality built-in through an applet or in settings (I have first-hand experience with Plasma and Windows, can't say for others)

EDIT: grammar

events.target_title: gnome-session should not save/restore RequiredComponents (causes upgrade failure when switching to systemd startup)

note.body:
>  It turns out that users can still enable session auto-saving

Isn't implementing the XSM Protocol a core task of gnome-session?

[man page gnome-session(1)](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-session/blob/master/doc/man/gnome-session.1#L29) here in the repository says so:
`\fIgnome-session\fP is an X11R6 session manager. It can manage GNOME applications as well as any X11R6 SM compliant application.`


The first link in the "Links" section on [https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement) is to [More Than You Ever Wanted To Know About XSMP](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement/NotesOnXSMP) on Gnome wiki by Dan Winship.

The X11R7.7 XSM Protocol specification [https://www.x.org/releases/X11R7.7/doc/libSM/xsmp.html] is not tied to an X server:
>  There was much discussion over whether the XSMP protocol should use X as the transport protocol or whether it should use its own independent transport. It was decided that it would use an independent protocol for several reasons. First, the Session Manager should be able to manage programs that do not maintain an X connection.

The functionality provided by XSM remains useful under wayland and systemd.
 
2 days ago on a laptop I was installing Debian sid on, I wanted to disable some autostart services (the a11y background services), and noticed the news announced here: https://blogs.gnome.org/benzea/2019/10/01/gnome-3-34-is-now-managed-using-systemd/ .
I failed to find a design document driving this ongoing effort. Looking for that I found this issue, and I now am doubting there is any such a document, I am afraid there is no clear direction.

Specifically, I discovered the new `X-GNOME-HiddenUnderSystemd=true` entry in the .desktop files in `/etc/xdg/autostart`. I found it in the comment in the blog post. I also noticed that similar functionality is provided in the .service files for D-Bus activation (eg: /usr/share/dbus-1/services/org/a11y.Bus.service), by the `SystemdService=` key (Documentation: search "SystemdService" in https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-daemon.1.html and https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html ).
  Then I reviewed the [freedesktop.org Desktop Application Autostart Specification]( https://specifications.freedesktop.org/autostart-spec/0.5/index.html) and wondered what is the difference between a spec compliant `NotShowIn=GNOME` and a custom `X-GNOME-HiddenUnderSystemd=true` (apart from compatibility with downgrading of gnome-session package).
The I came to this issue to write this comment.

Without any intention to be abrasive, these above are my doubts. They are summarized by: is the session save and restore functionality going down the drain without alternatives?

Now my 2 cents. 
I wonder if implementing a systemd generator to convert the .desktop files in /etc/xdg/autostart would be any better:
*  it could easily handle the .desktop files from ~/.config/gnome-session/saved-session/  both the obsolete ones this issue is about AND the good ones from a good previous saved session.
* With a generator, only the management of the processes would be handed over to systemd in the form of unit files,
* while the management of the session in the XSM meaning would stay untouched, implemented by the .desktop files.
* The applicable existing specifications (XSM, XDG Autostart) would stay relevant and would guide the development.

Regards,

Marco Gamberoni
